title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributing to cryptoQuotes
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("serkor1/cryptoQuotes", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to cryptoQuotes
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: charts supports various indicators relative strenght index (rsi())-, Moving Average Convergence Divergence (macd())- various moving average indicators. can passed respective arguments follows,
code: ## chart BTC ## with candlesticks ## and various indicators chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = kline(),   sub    = list(     volume(),     rsi(),     macd()   ),   indicator = list(     sma(n = 7),     sma(n = 21),     bollinger_bands()   ) )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: charts supports passing event_data, type data.frame, can plotted chart. example plotting crossing MA, Based cross indicator, BTC pair can now subset, processed accordingly. Finally, crosses can plotted using chart() follows,
code: ## Calculate moving averages ## SMA(7) and SMA(10) BTC$short_SMA <- TTR::SMA(   x = BTC$close,   n = 7 )  BTC$long_SMA <- TTR::SMA(   x = BTC$close,   n = 21 )  ## Determine the cross ## from below BTC$cross <- as.numeric(   lag(BTC$short_SMA) < BTC$long_SMA &     BTC$short_SMA > BTC$long_SMA  ) ## create event data ## and store it as a data.rfrae event_data <- subset(   BTC,   cross == 1 )  # 1.1) Extract the index # from the event data index <- zoo::index(   event_data )  # 1.2) Convert the coredata # into a data.frame event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(event_data) )  # 1.3) Add the index into the data.frame # case insensitive event_data$index <- index  # 1.4) add events to the data. # here we use Buys and Sells. event_data$event <- 'Bull Cross' event_data$color <- 'darkgray' ## add the events ## the chart, along ## with Moving averages ## and the Bollinger Bands ## in a candlestick chart chart(   ticker    = BTC,   main      = kline(),   indicator = list(     bollinger_bands(),     sma(n = 7),     sma(n = 21)   ),   event_data = event_data )

title: Dealing with Time Zones
text: time zone Github servers CET, returned OHLC-V data UTC demonstrated , time zones can converted using xts::tzone()-function. example converting BTC CET, table original index UTC converted index CET, Time zone comparsion
code: ## Get hourly ## BTC between ## 16:00 and 18:00 from ## yesterday xts::tzone(   BTC <- get_quote(     ticker   = "BTCUSD",     source   = "kraken",     interval = "1h",     futures  = FALSE,     from     = from,     to       = to   ) ) #> [1] "UTC" ## 1) Change time ## zone to CET BTC_CET <- BTC xts::tzone(BTC_CET) <- "CET"

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with {quantmod} and {TTR}
text: BTC can passed charting functions, used quantmod::tradeModel()-functions.

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with {quantmod} and {TTR}
text: example use quantmod::tradeModel()-function BTC-object,
code: ## 1) specify ## the model lhs <- quantmod::Next(quantmod::OpCl(BTC)) rhs <- quantmod::Lag(quantmod::OpHi(BTC),0:3)  BTC_model <- quantmod::specifyModel(   formula = lhs ~ rhs )  ## 2) build the ## model built_model <-  quantmod::buildModel(   x            = BTC_model,   method       = 'lm',   training.per = range(head(zoo::index(BTC), 10)) )  ## 3) trade the model quantmod::tradeModel(built_model, leverage = 2) #>  #>   Model:  lm1730986104.10517  #>  #>   C.A.G.R.:  39.35%  H.P.R.:  28.26%  #>  #>   Returns by period summary: #>  #>              weekly monthly quarterly yearly #>     Max.     25.77%  48.73%    31.94% 51.46% #>     3rd Qu.   8.02%  29.69%    22.19% 51.46% #>     Mean      2.19%   9.12%    15.49% 51.46% #>     Median   -1.77%   1.88%    12.43% 51.46% #>     2rd Qu.  -5.24% -13.74%     7.27% 51.46% #>     Min.    -21.19% -18.69%     2.10% 51.46% #>  #>   Period to date returns: #>  #>              weekly monthly quarterly yearly #>              17.33%  12.43%    12.43% 51.46%

code: ## extract long-short ## ratio on Bitcoin ## using the hourly chart LS_BTC <- try(    get_lsratio(     ticker   = "XBTUSDT",     source   = "kraken",     interval = "1h"   ) ) #> Error in base::tryCatch(base::withCallingHandlers({ :  #>   ✖ Couldn't find "XBTUSDT" on "kraken". #> ✔ Run available_tickers(source = 'kraken', futures = TRUE) to see available #>   tickers. #> ℹ If the error persists please submit a bug report. ## extract long-short ## ratio on Bitcoin ## using the hourly chart LS_BTC <- get_lsratio(   ticker   = "PF_XBTUSD",   source   = "kraken",   interval = "1h" ) #>                       long  short ls_ratio #> 2024-11-07 08:00:00 0.7228 0.2772 2.607504 #> 2024-11-07 09:00:00 0.7235 0.2765 2.616637 #> 2024-11-07 10:00:00 0.7187 0.2813 2.554924 #> 2024-11-07 11:00:00 0.7222 0.2778 2.599712 #> 2024-11-07 12:00:00 0.7148 0.2852 2.506311 #> 2024-11-07 13:00:00 0.7130 0.2870 2.484321 # show a sample of  # the available tickers sample(   x = available_tickers(     source  = "kraken",     futures = TRUE   ),   size = 5 ) #> [1] "PF_BALUSD"        "PF_RAYUSD"        "PF_QTUMUSD"       "FF_XBTUSD_241129" #> [5] "PF_VIDTUSD"

title: A Guide on Charting and Custom Indicators
text: start creating simple chart-object volume ’s indicator,
code: # 1) create a simple chart # object #  # NOTE: The chart is wrapped in # plotly::layout() to avoid # duplicating xaxis when the # custom indicators are added chart_object <- plotly::layout(   chart(     ticker = BTC,     main   = kline(),     sub    = list(       volume()     ),     options = list(       dark = FALSE     )   ),   xaxis = list(     showticklabels = FALSE   ) )

title: A Guide on Charting and Custom Indicators
text: Assume trading strategy follows sin()-curve throughout period interest. starting point generating indicator, sin_indicator ’s basic form can charted follows, sin_indicator can added chart_object using plotly::subplot also handles theming,
code: # 1) generate sin-indicator sin_indicator <- data.frame(     index         = zoo::index(BTC),     sin_indicator = sin(seq(0,8*pi,length.out=nrow(BTC)))    ) # 1) create a plotly-object # with the sin-indicator sin_indicator <- plotly::layout(    margin= list(l = 5, r = 5, b = 5),   p = plotly::plot_ly(     data = sin_indicator,     y    = ~sin_indicator,     x    = ~index,     type = "scatter",     mode = "lines",     name = "sin"   ),   yaxis = list(     title = NA   ),   xaxis = list(     title = NA   ) ) # 2) display the  # indicator sin_indicator # 1) append the sin_indicator # to the chart object chart_object <- plotly::subplot(   # ensures that plots are    # vertically aligned   nrows = 2,   heights = c(     0.7,     0.2   ),   chart_object,   sin_indicator,   shareX = FALSE,   titleY = FALSE )  # 2) display the chart # object chart_object

title: A Guide on Charting and Custom Indicators
text: Assume trading strategy goes long (short) every time price () linear regression line. indicator can defined follows, lm_indicator ’s basic form can charted follows, lm_indicator can added chart_object using plotly::add_lines also handles theming,
code: # 1) linear regression # line lm_indicator <- data.frame(   y = fitted(     lm(       close ~ time,       data = data.frame(         time = 1:nrow(BTC),         close = BTC$close       )     )   ),   index = zoo::index(BTC) ) # 1) display the linear # regression line on # an empty chart plotly::add_lines(   p    = plotly::plotly_empty(),   data = lm_indicator,   y    = ~y,   x    = ~index,   inherit = FALSE,   xaxis = "x1",   yaxis = "y2",   name  = "regression" ) # 1) add the regression # line to the chart_object plotly::layout(   margin = list(l = 5, r = 5, b = 5, t = 65),   plotly::add_lines(     p       = chart_object,     data    = lm_indicator,     y       = ~y,     x       = ~index,     inherit = FALSE,     xaxis   = "x1",     yaxis   = "y2",     name    = "regression"   ),   yaxis = list(     title = NA   ),   xaxis = list(     title = NA   ) )

title: A Guide on Charting and Custom Indicators
text: Creating custom indicators chart()-functions follows standard {plotly} syntax. Two examples charted {cryptoQuotes} covered. Note: full pipeline charting indicators, custom built-, released sometime future.

title: Usecase
text: high-level API-client provides open access cryptocurrency market data without relying low-level coding API-keys. Currently actively traded cryptocurrencies 1 major exchanges available, see wiki details. vignette explore case study showcase capabilities {cryptoQuotes}; Dogecoin-market react Elon Musks following tweet, Tweet Elon Musk - timezone CET.

title: Usecase
text: Elon Musk tweeted (Well, now X’ed) Dogecoin January 14, 06.18 (UTC) - Dogecoin rallied. determine fast markets reacted tweets, get market data Dogecoin 1 minute intervals day tweeeted using get_quotes()-function, returns object class xts zoo 61 rows. calculate rally within first minute tweet, can use {xts}-syntax determine magnitude, Dogecoin rallied 8.71% within minute Elon Musk tweeted.
code: ## DOGEUSDT the day ## of the tweet on the ## 1m chart DOGE <- cryptoQuotes::get_quote(   ticker   = 'DOGE-USDT',   interval = '1m',   source   = 'kucoin',   futures  = FALSE,   from     = '2022-01-14 07:00:00',   to       = '2022-01-14 08:00:00' ) ## extrat the ## tweet moment tweet_moment <- DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"]  ## calculate  ## rally cat(   "Doge closed:", round((tweet_moment$close/tweet_moment$open - 1),4) * 100, "%" ) #> Doge closed: 8.71 %

title: Usecase
text: can visualize rally candlestick charts using chart()- kline()-function,
code: ## chart the ## price action ## using klines cryptoQuotes::chart(   ticker     = DOGE,   main       = cryptoQuotes::kline(),   indicator  = list(     cryptoQuotes::bollinger_bands()   ),   sub  = list(     cryptoQuotes::volume()   ),   options = list(     dark = FALSE   ) )

what: Charting price action with event lines
title: Usecase
text: create , presumably, better visual overview can add event lines using event_data-argument, takes data.frame kind argument, event data, can passed chart follows,
code: ## 1) create event data.frame ## by subsetting the data event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(     DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"]   ) )  ## 1.1) add the index  ## to the event_data event_data$index <- zoo::index(   DOGE["2022-01-14 07:18:00"] )  # 1.2) add event label # to the data event_data$event <- 'Elon Musk Tweets'  # 1.3) add color to the # event label event_data$color <- 'steelblue' ## 1) chart the ## price action ## using klines cryptoQuotes::chart(   ticker     = DOGE,   event_data = event_data,   main       = cryptoQuotes::kline(),   indicator  = list(     cryptoQuotes::bollinger_bands()   ),   sub = list(     cryptoQuotes::volume()   ),   options = list(     dark = FALSE   ) )

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # script start;    # 1) unnamed assert   # expressions   foo <- function(     a,     b) {      # assert without     # named expressions     cryptoQuotes:::assert(       is.numeric(a),       is.numeric(b)     )      a + b    }    # 1.1) returns   # the regular R error   # messages in cli-format   foo(     a = "1",     b = "2"   )    # 2) named assert   # expressions   foo <- function(     a,     b) {      cryptoQuotes:::assert(       "{.arg a} is not {.cls numeric}" =  is.numeric(a),       "{.arg a} is not {.cls numeric}" = is.numeric(b)     )      a + b    }    # 2.2) Returns   # custom error-messages   # in cli-format   foo(     a = "1",     b = "2"   )    # 3) custom error   # messages on   foo <- function(     a) {      cryptoQuotes:::assert(       is.numeric(a),       error_message = sprintf(         fmt = "{.val %s} is not a numeric value.",         a       )     )      a    }    # 2.2) Returns   # custom error-messages with   # passed values in cli-format   foo(     a = "1"   )    # script end; } # }

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrate_window
code: # script start;  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- cryptoQuotes::split_window(   xts = cryptoQuotes::FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTC),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- cryptoQuotes::calibrate_window(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly stopifnot(   setequal(     zoo::index(BTC),     zoo::index(FGIndex)   ) )   # script end;

title: remove upper and lower bounds from an XTS object — remove_bound

title: remove upper and lower bounds from an XTS object — remove_bound
code: # script start;  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTC),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- cryptoQuotes::split_window(   xts = cryptoQuotes::FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTC),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- cryptoQuotes::calibrate_window(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly stopifnot(   setequal(     zoo::index(BTC),     zoo::index(FGIndex)   ) )   # script end;

Version 1.3.2
text: CRAN release: 2024-11-07

title: Version 1.3.2
text: bitmart updated futures API. backend updated accordingly. Unit-tests updated now get_quote()-functions tested equality passed inferred interval.

title: Version 1.3.2
text: read_xts() write_xts() reads stores xts-objects. functions essentially just wrappers zoo::read.zoo() zoo::write.zoo(). Thank @gokberkcan7 suggestion.

title: Version 1.3.2
text: chart()-function now exported .svg-images 4k resolution via modebar. chart()-function now interactive supports drawing lines rectangles via modebar. also possible interactively change title subtitle double clicking (Thank @andreltr suggestion. See Discussion). chart()-function now new option static equal FALSE default. FALSE chart can edited, annotated explored interactively. chart()-function now new option palette set “hawaii” default. See hcl.pals() accepted values. chart()-function now new option scale set 1 default. Scales fonts chart. chart()-function now new option width set 0.9 default. Sets overall linewidth chart. (Thank @andreltr suggestion. See Discussion)
code: # static = FALSE chart(   ticker  = BTC,   main    = kline(),     indicator = line(     sma(n = 7),     sma(n = 14),     sma(n = 21)   ),   options = list(     static = FALSE,     palette = "hawaii"   )  ) # static = TRUE chart(   ticker  = BTC,   main    = kline(),   indicator = line(     sma(n = 7),     sma(n = 14),     sma(n = 21)   ),   options = list(     static  = TRUE,     palette = "Set 3"   )  )

title: Version 1.3.2
text: {cryptoQuotes} now supports following exchanges: Crypto.com Huobi MEXC

title: Version 1.3.2
text: Fixed bug chart()-function warning given called using namespace qualified function calls (Issue #13) Fixed bug chart()-function legend wouldn’t show unless main-chart indicator included. (Issue #13)

title: Version 1.3.2
text: Removed 1s Binance spot Removed 3m, 6h 3d Bitmart spot intervals removed either discontinued, non-existent.

title: Version 1.3.1
text: NOTE: update package longer considered experimental. Removed deprecated functions getQuote()-, getFGIndex()- getLSRatio()-functions. Removed decprecated functions availableExchanges()-, availableIntervals()- availableTickers()-functions. functions planned deleted 1.4.0 - however, decided aim JOSS- rOpenSci-subscription requires degree stability. Hence deletion function 1.3.0. expect 1.4.0 released rOpenSci-submission acceptance 🙏

title: Version 1.3.1
text: smi()-function, subchart-indicator built TTR::SMI()-function. donchian_channel()-function, main chart-indicator built TTR::DonchianChannel()-function
code: chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = kline(),   indicator = list(     donchian_channel()   ),   sub = list(     smi()   ) )

title: Version 1.3.1
text: chart()-function now proper light-theme available isn’t default plotly-values. charts now displays date ranges subtitles. bollinger_bands()-function now accepts color-argument. can passed Hexadecimal-colors , "blue" example. new main chart function introduced. pline() univariate price chart based either open, high, low close prices.
code: chart(   ticker = BTC,   main   = pline(price = "close"),   indicator = list(     bollinger_bands(     color = "steelblue"   )   ),   sub = list(     volume()   ),   options = list(     dark = FALSE   ) )

title: Version 1.2.0
text: arguments now flexible, supports passing Sys.Date() Sys.time() directly get-functions. getQuote() now returns 100 pips preceding specified date, = NULL. returns 100 pips, Sys.Date(), specified date. getQuote()-function can now used follows;
code: ## Specifying from ## date only; ## ## Returns 10 pips getQuote(  ticker   = 'BTCUSDT',  interval = '1d'  from     = as.character(Sys.Date() - 10)  ) ## Specifying to ## date only; ## ## Returns 100 pips getQuote(  ticker   = 'BTCUSDT',  interval = '1d'  to     = as.character(Sys.Date())  )
